sources.news_title: Canada joins international call to protect Gaza journalists, allow foreign media
sources.text:
Canada has signed onto a multi-country statement that demands Israel stop banning foreign journalists from entering Gaza and that local journalists be protected in the Palestinian territories.
Canada co-founded the Media Freedom Coalition in 2020 and has signed dozens of statements on issues in Hong Kong, Sudan and previously the West Bank.
Ottawa was not among the 27 countries who signed a call Thursday for Israel to allow “independent foreign media access” into Gaza, and for journalists to be protect across Israel and the Palestinian territories.
What we know so far as Israel prepares its offensive against Gaza City
Global Affairs Canada said Thursday it would provide a statement to The Canadian Press but did not do so, and Canada was added onto the statement that evening following media coverage.
The statement came after Canada and others condemned Israel for deliberately killing Al Jazeera journalist Anas Al-Sharif, after claiming he had led a cell of Hamas.
The only other time Canada had not signed a multi-country statement from the coalition was during the 2021 election campaign.

sources.news_title: Global Coalition Demands Israel End Media Blackout in Gaza, Investigate Journalist Deaths
sources.text:
August 22, 2025:A growing international outcry is mounting against Israel’s media restrictions in Gaza, as a coalition of democracies has demanded open access for journalists and accountability for attacks on the press.
The Media Freedom Coalition, which includes countries such as Germany, Japan, Canada, Ireland, and the UK, said in a joint statement on Thursday that journalists must be allowed to operate freely in conflict zones. The group emphasized that reporting from Gaza is essential for the world to understand the humanitarian and political consequences of the war.
Since October 2023, when Israel launched its offensive on Gaza, conditions for reporters have become increasingly perilous. Press groups estimate more than 270 journalists have been killed in the enclave over the past 22 months — one of the deadliest periods for the profession on record. Many others face detention and intimidation across Gaza, the West Bank, and East Jerusalem.
The coalition condemned the deaths and harassment of media workers and warned that targeting journalists violates international humanitarian law. It called for full investigations into all cases and for those responsible to be held to account.
Alongside press freedom, the statement also urged a ceasefire, safe passage of aid, and a path toward a two-state peace settlement, echoing growing demands from humanitarian organizations.
Israel has justified its restrictions on international media entry as security measures, but critics argue the blackout is designed to suppress scrutiny of military actions in Gaza.
Meanwhile, the humanitarian crisis deepens. According to local health officials, Israeli air and ground operations have killed over 62,000 Palestinians and wounded more than 157,000. Thousands remain missing under collapsed buildings as bombardments continue.
The coalition’s statement reflects mounting pressure on Israel to not only protect civilians but also safeguard the press — a demand that has so far gone unanswered.
